title: Linear Inequalities
description: Learn to solve and graph linear inequalities, understanding when solutions represent ranges rather than single values.
subject: Mathematics
achievementDescription: Master the concepts and applications of linear inequalities

text.introduction: Linear inequalities are similar to linear equations but use inequality symbols (<, >, ≤, ≥) instead of equals. They represent ranges of values rather than single solutions, making them perfect for real-world situations involving minimum and maximum constraints.

sections.title: Understanding Inequality Symbols
sections.content:
**The Four Main Symbols:**
• < means 'less than'
• > means 'greater than'
• ≤ means 'less than or equal to'
• ≥ means 'greater than or equal to'

**Examples:**
• x < 5 means x can be 4, 3, 2, 1, ... but not 5
• x ≥ 10 means x can be 10, 11, 12, 13, ...
• 2 < x < 7 means x is between 2 and 7

sections.title: Solving Linear Inequalities
sections.content:
**Same Rules as Equations, with ONE Exception:**
1. Add/subtract the same number from both sides
2. Multiply/divide by positive numbers normally
3. **FLIP the inequality sign when multiplying/dividing by negative numbers**

**Example:** Solve -2x + 6 > 12
• Step 1: -2x + 6 > 12
• Step 2: -2x > 6
• Step 3: x < -3 (sign flipped because we divided by -2)

**Check:** If x = -4: -2(-4) + 6 = 14 > 12 ✓

sections.title: Graphing on Number Lines
sections.content:
**Open vs. Closed Circles:**
• Open circle (○) for < or > (value not included)
• Closed circle (●) for ≤ or ≥ (value included)

**Direction of Arrow:**
• Arrow points right for > or ≥
• Arrow points left for < or ≤

**Examples:**
• x > 3: Open circle at 3, arrow right
• x ≤ -1: Closed circle at -1, arrow left

sections.title: Compound Inequalities
sections.content:
**Two Types:**

**AND Compound (∩):** a < x < b
Example: -2 < x < 5
Solution: x is between -2 and 5

**OR Compound (∪):** x < a OR x > b
Example: x < -1 OR x > 4
Solution: x is less than -1 or greater than 4

questions.question: Which graph represents x < 4?
questions.explanation: x < 4 means values less than 4, so open circle (4 not included) with arrow pointing left.

exercises.title: Ghana Budget Planning
exercises.instructions: Use inequalities to solve budget constraint problems typical in Ghanaian households.
exercises.hint: Identify whether the constraint is a maximum (≤) or minimum (≥) requirement.

scenarioChallenges.title: School Fundraising in Ghana
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Akosua's class needs to raise at least GH₵500 for a school trip. They sell water for GH₵1 each and have already raised GH₵150. Each student can sell a maximum of 20 bottles.
tasks: Write an inequality for the minimum bottles needed
If there are 25 students, can they reach their goal?
What's the range of bottles each student should sell?
learningObjectives: Calculate feasible ranges for group activities
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: School fundraising is common in Ghana, with students often selling items or organizing events to support school activities and trips.
